content.description: Face climby crux to varied fingers to hands and liebacking. Slightly less than vertical.
content.protection: #00 and #0 nice for the crux. Then varied up to 3.5". A bolt protects a slightly soft part.
content.location: This route angles up the slab just right of Run Like Hell.

content.description:
If this route wasn't guarded by 100 feet of heinous choss, it would be a mega classic. While the dubious first pitch isn't nearly as dangerous as it was for  the first ascensionists, it still has some loose bits. Tread lightly.

P1-5.10 Climb fingers in a shallow right-facing corner up to a loose ledge, then up double cracks. Continue up and left (watch for loose bits) to the top of a small pillar. 110'

P2-5.12+ Money. Climb the beautiful offset splitter to  the top of some blocks (could probably be trundled, but they are HUGE). 90'
content.location: This is the obvious long thin, offset splitter up and left of Goodbye Cruel World.

content.description: This is a long hand to offwidth corner that's featured on the right and varnished on the left.  Features and variations keep it moderate.  Very clean. 60m rope gets you down.
content.protection: Blue camalot to #4.5 or #5 camalot (new #5 works well)
content.location: Located on the south facing wall beyond the right end of The Wall.  Walk past the prow forming the right edge of The Wall and go around the corner about 200-300' and look for the obvious dihedral.  Technically this wall is between The Wall and 75 Cairns but much closer to The Wall.

content.description: The route offers a good diversion from your typical  Creek corner climb. With a variety of sizes and moves it climbs more like a pitch you'd find in one of the bigger granite arenas than a featureless sandstone thrutch-fest.                               Find the right facing corner with a wide crack at the base. A wide, featured flare warms you up for an enjoyable section of hands/thin hands. Continue up the corner to a somewhat technical stemming crux, power up a beautifully "podded" stretch of steep hands, make a corner change and finish by cranking a small wide hands roof.
content.protection: Singles of 3/4" to 1.25", Doubles of 1.50" to 3.5", include one each of #4, #5, #6 Camalots.
content.location: Which One's Pink? is about 50 yards past Learning To  Fly. Look for a clean, right facing corner with a flare at it's base. A two bolt anchor with chains are found atop the climb but are not visible from the ground.

content.description: Awkward start to a short finger crack with some feet! Probably makes a nice warmup for those with smaller fingers.
content.protection: BD sizes: .3-.5, heavy on .4 cams.
content.location: Located between Dirty Girl & Goodbye Cruel World. Large vertical boulder near base.

content.description: Start up a ramp to varied climbing in a closed corner. Look for face holds. Then a long hands to 1" corner. This route is much better than it looks from the ground. Trust me.
content.protection: Varied rack and bring several 1" for the top.
content.location: Another minute to the right of the last route in the book. Just before Learning to Fly - the amazing overhanging .75" splitter. You can't miss this one.

content.description: Big right-facing corner left of Sorrow. 20 feet of easy scrambling leads to a sandy ledge where the plaque (maybe) resides. Start on a large loose flake and head into a fun corner. Crux felt like small bulge midway which is red Camalots. There is a helpful thin splitter on the left as you near the finish. Last 10 feet is a little sandy.
content.protection: Golds decreasing to yellow TCUs. Slings for bulge or have your cams walk. Two-chain anchor.
content.location: Around corner to the right as approach trail meets the cliff. Big corner left of obvious splitter Sorrow.

climbs.name: Tight as a Tourniquet
climbs.fa: Steve Quinlan and Chris Ann Crysdale

content.description: This route is listed as unknown in Bloom's guide but that has been corrected in Karl's new book. The climbing is fun and engaging fingers and tips on good stone, with a couple of sections where it thins down.
content.protection: Singles .5 or red Alien then doubles from .4/yellow down to green c3/purple Metolius, with extra in the blue Metolius/green Alien size
content.location: 2nd route to the right of Pigs on The Wing, immediately left of Great Gig...

content.description: Climb the hand crack to the tide pod.  Pulling into and out of the pod is the challenge.  Good for the aspiring trad climber tagging along in the creek.
content.protection: .75 to 4 BD
content.location: Located just right of Exploding Star near the top of the approach trail.

climbs.name: Sorrow
climbs.fa: Josh Gross, Sam Lightner, Sandy Boling, Zoe and Al

content.description: This is the obvious splitter half way between The Schoolmaster and Run Like Hell. Starts as wide hands and crushes down to tips. There is a tad bit of loose stuff at the base.
content.protection: From a couple of each from 3.5 friends down to .4 alien (blue). Take and extra #4 friend for the last moves.
content.location: Start on the obvious ledge above the trail. The route is labeled #2 on the picture of The Schoolmaster.

content.description:
The Schoolmaster is what we named the tower at the very northwest end of The Wall. The summit of this tower is roughly the size of an ironing board. The start is found between the tower and the wall. Getting up on either side of the tower requires a little fourth class on loose ground.

P1 5.9 hands, finger, and then a chimney. Decent gear, but don't fall. It ends on a large ledge with good anchors.

P2 goes up the obvious arete. Its best approached as a "French Free" climb with 5.10 moves between good bolts. A sling to stand in at a couple of the bolts will be useful, but a solid 5.10 Indian Creek climber should be fine without full-on aiders. Two boulder problems make this a very difficult endeavor to free. Also, keep in mind there are loose, giant blocks you have to contend with as it is the desert! The stand-up at the summit is a dizzying move. Despite the 5.10, A0 rating, this is not a giveaway.
content.protection: A few hand and finger pieces for the start, then maybe a #5 in the back of the chimney. You need about a dozen quickdraws for the last pitch.
content.location:
The obvious tower as you come up the trail to The Wall. Two raps on a 70 meter rope will reach the ground. A 60 may reach, but it will be close.

Its labelled #1 in the picture.

content.description: Start up some loose blocks to the striking splitter.  Crank up the angling splitter 60 feet to the chains.
content.protection: fingers-hands, maybe a 4 camalot for the bottom of the splitter with a sling.
content.location: To the left of Wish You Were Here

climbs.name: Power Nap
climbs.fa: Jay brown, heather hicks, James from?

content.description:
The crux for me was the overhung #6's near the roof at the top. Otherwise pretty fun wide stuff. Mostly #4's and #5 climbing. I walked by this for 4 yrs now and finally did it.

The roof traverse is #2's peeeerfect hands!!
content.protection:
1-.4

1-.5

1-1

2-2's

3-4's

2-5's

1-6

Fixed biners on anchor.
content.location:
20'~ before Sorrow route. Plaque says .10+

80 m rope is perfect. Or 2 ropes, maybe a 70m?

content.description: Cool. Cruiser hands to thin hands splitter followed by a fun crack switch to locks on a dark rock shield.
content.protection: Mostly red Camalots. A few golds for the start and a couple of greens near the switch and finish.
content.location: 20 feet right of the long (160') gold-size left-facing corner Comfortably Numb. At the top of small talus slope right of main alcove.

content.description:
An excellent and forgiving finger crack located just beyond The Wall's beaten path. This crack and the other 3 (actually seams) around it catch your eye from literally miles away, but if you hike up here expecting another Wiggins, you might be left wanting. That said, it's another good 5.10 on a wall with a lot of good 5.10s, and if you've already hiked over to the right side of the Wall, it's worth going a little further. Sunshine and solitude guaranteed.

Crisp, splitter fingers. Should be a good size for most. It's sustained, but lots of good feet take some of the bite out of it. Have fun!
content.protection: 0.3 - 0.4 C4 sizes
content.location:
It's located so far right that it may not even be on "The Wall" anymore, but not as far as some of the others posted here. It's on the sunny side of the right-side prow, the leftmost splitter on the clean, varnished face as viewed from 211.

Follow the trail to just below Freebird, where you hit a barrier of choss. You can go over this via a couple loose 4th class options, or hike low and around. Continue traversing for another ~100 feet, past a small pillar, then hike up, left, and slightly back when you can see the varnished face with four right-angling seams/splitters. Outside the Wall is the leftmost of these.

content.description: Money is a stellar left facing corner that starts as hands and slowly pinches down to tight fingers.  There is a good rest before the finger section which is probably the crux.  Could be a four star route if it cleans up some.
content.protection: #2 to .3 Camalots.
content.location: Left of Freebird in a left facing corner thats shady for most of the day.

content.description: A long varied crack that starts in a dirty, but easy big hands flake. A bit of OW, liebacking, fingers, hands, etc. Quite varied. The top is very cool. A voyage. I got bored with the whole Pink Floyd thing! So I switched to ABBA!
content.protection: Everything from 1" to wide.
content.location: Up the hill to the right of Pigs on the Wing. Just right of Great Gig in the Sky. Anchors are not visible from below.

content.description: Navigate offwidth pods and bulges to get to big hands that narrow to thin hands, then make the exciting crack switch to brain damage at the mini shelf on that route, then take the thin hands crack to the anchor. Overall, Fun movement and splitter/good rock.
content.protection: .75-6. Generally, the crack narrows the higher you get.
content.location: Left of Brain Damage, right of Dogs of War. Predominately clean crack, with a few chock stones that aren't going anywhere (we tried).

content.description: Splitter, overhanging .75" crack. I put an anchor on this but could barely toprope the moves so I lured Didier up there and he sent it after about 6 tries over a few days. Didier disappeared into a Christian commune two years later. I sent it 7 years later!
content.protection: One or two .3 Camalots. Five or six .4 Camalots.
content.location: Look for the amazing overhanging splitter on the right side of the main alcove, past Time, Dancing Queen. Flat area in front of angled boulder. Slab start.

content.description: Face moves over a bulge to small roof, then fingers to hands. Finish with a 5.9 chimney thats hard to protect.
content.protection: Lots of small cams and a #5 friend to protect just below the roof (Its not an offwidth move).
content.location: Eighty feet right of The Judge and Run Like Hell.

climbs.name: The Judge
climbs.fa: Josh Gross, Sam Lightner, Jason Keith, Chrissy

content.description: Start on Run Like Hell and take the obvious splitter above the corner. As the crack tapers down move to the arete and face climb.
content.protection: Friends from 3.5 down to 00 Metolious. The smaller the cams, the higher you are able to protect! Take 1 quickdraw, as well.
content.location: Splitter crack left of Run Like Hell and Wish You Were Here. Its labelled as #3 on The Schoolmaster photo.

content.description: This climb ascends a left facing corner that is shaped like a crescent moon. A little like "Chest Full of Kind" with some interesting underclinging at the end. Can get pretty sandy after a good rain.
content.protection: Several 2.5-3.0" and a couple 1.5" for the end.
content.location: FAR left side of The Wall, not far from the forming arch.

content.description: Fun slightly overhung fist crack to wide fists.
content.protection: several #4's and #5's.  2 #3s, 1 #.5 to protect finishing moves. Maybe a few #1's until the base of crack is reached.

climbs.name: The Great Gig in the Sky

content.description: A bolt gets you into a stem/chimney. Hands head up to a pedestal. Then hands amd pods slowly close to fingers in a corner.
content.protection: Hands to .5". You need several 1.5" to .75" for the finish. Save one or two .5" for the end.
content.location: JUst up the hill and right from Pigs on the Wing. Behind a large boulder. Look for the bolt just off the ground.

content.description: The clean, black left-facing corner just opposite the Schoolmaster.
content.protection: A few 0.5 Camalots and blue TCU's, but mostly 0.4 Camalots/yellow TCU's (6 or 7 will sew it up).

content.description: Probably the easiest route on The Wall.  Has 2 precarious looking blocks, we load tested them both but be careful and pull at your own risk.
content.protection: Many gold and blue camalots with a couple reds at the top
content.location: Go to the far right end of The Wall and scramble up a gully to the base of the obvious splitter hand crack with 2 blocks.

content.description: 1" in a corner to blocky section with two bolts to hands. Just as a warning, the route is about 35m, so watch those ends if you lower off.
content.protection:
A big cam is nice for the start, then 1" to hands.

One bolt is unnecessary since I cleaned a block and revealed a crack.
content.location: Just left of Run Like Hell and The Judge

content.description: This fun route climbs flared splitter hands to a ledge where you have the option of continuing up the direct route which widens from 4" to a squeeze with a corner change (the FA took the direct route) or stepping left a couple feet and climbing a thin hands/hands splitter that starts ~7 feet above the ledge.  It's a big reach to the hands splitter but a fun variation.
content.protection: BD #2-#6 for the direct line, more 2.5-3.0" for the variation. 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Left of "Finer 39'r" maybe 100 yards.  The line is obvious from the approach trail.

content.description: The route is 150 yds. right of the main corner in the wall. It has a plaque (unless the smasher got to it) and starts just left of dancing queen?
content.location: It starts 10'left of a .11+ on a face (dancing queen?). it has a 6' flake on the ground at the start. start in an acute corner with an overhanging section about 15' to a sustained acute hands flare corner to 2 fixes on the left wall.

content.description: Dogs of War is the wedge just to the left of Brain Damage. Climb the dirty and adventurous wedge as it steepens to the base of the final fist crack. I don't think this gets climbed much since we were all pretty dusty after. Get on it and it should clean up nice!
content.protection:
#3 & #4 camalots

ANCHOR: Slings on bolts. Inspect before lowering and backup if needed!

content.description: The clean left-facing corner immediately right of Dirty Girl. Starts fists/cups in shallow slot into tight hands to fingers. Can stem to the splitter of Dirty Girl in the upper 1/2, or contrive it out and stick to the corner...either way is fun. Would be a great line if even just twice as long, as is it makes for a decent warm-up. The fact that you can hit up both of these shorties off the same anchor makes them more worthwhile.
content.protection: .4-new #4 BD, chains.
content.location: Immediately right of Dirty Girl, in the curve of the amphitheater where the Wall goes from South to West facing. Between the routes "Just a Brick" and "Wish You Were Beer".

content.description:
Short, slabby, wavy splitter hands and fingers with some face features. You can use either the crack to the left (hands/fists) or the corner to the right--Dirty Woman-- (fingers) in the upper 1/2.

This is a pretty good route for the grade in the Creek, and another decent warm-up option for the Wall. I'd give it another star, but it's just so short...

Most of the loose bits were cleaned, but there are a couple blocks in the bottom of the left crack and some inevitable friable pieces.
content.protection: (2x).3-#2 BD, chains.
content.location: In the center of the Wall, in the curve of the amphitheater where the Wall transitions from South to West facing. Between the routes "Just a Brick" and "Wish You Were Beer".

climbs.name: Dancing Queen
climbs.fa: Chris Kalous, and Jason and Will from Canada.

content.description: Thin torquing on fingers to hands to OW. The OW is pretty cool with some stacking required, but the crux is the start. Kinda bouldery. I would give it another star if it was longer.
content.protection: #0 TCU to (old) 4.5 and 5 camalot (One each  on the daddy sized is fine).
content.location: A splitter start on an undercut wall on a prow. Right of all the routes in the book just a minute or two. Before Time and Learning to Fly.

content.description: Crazy long, this route makes a good "warm-up" for the area. 160' of hands to wide hands in a left-facing corner. Rests aplenty keep the grade down. The crux is a short wide section halfway up. Double rope rappel.
content.location: This is the obvious long hands corner just left of Pigs On the Wing, to the right of Goodbye Cruel World.

content.description: Short fist to offwidth crack right of Dancing Queen.  Bolt anchor on left wall at the flat ledge.
content.protection: one #1 camalot for a constriction partway up, a couple #3 camalots, a couple (new)#4 camalots, and a (new)#5 or two.
content.location: Right of Dancing Queen, maybe 100 yards?

content.description: The climb begins with a good #3 placement and slowly but surely works its way up to #6.  It ends with a 2 bolt anchor, under a roof.  Couple good rest let you catch your breath before pushing on.  Being an off-width, the crux will be different for everyone.  As a larger guy, I found the crux to be the middle and Jerome thought it was the top 1/3.   It was given a 5.10+ but could be more like 5.11-.  Good rock and a great, physical off-width climb.  Don't forget to breathe!
content.protection: One #3, doubles form #4-6 (camalots).  You could probably get by with a single rack with a good bit of bumping.
content.location: I believe it's the 1st route to the right of "Learning to Fly", let me know if I'm wrong.

content.description: Brain Damage is around the corner to the right of the main alcove of the Wall.  It takes an awkward changing-corners crack through some wide pods and up a final stretch of nice thin-hands liebacking.
content.protection: An assortment of gear with many #1 Camalots.  A #4.5 (#5 C4) Camalot is helpful.

content.description: This route climbs a right-facing offwidth corner formed by a pillar leaning against the wall.  Climb a section of baggy #6 camalots to a pod using crack and nice face features.  Continue up 4-6" crack to a steeper section of easy stacking and the chains.
content.protection: #4-6 Camalots.  Chain anchor.
content.location: Far left side of the the Wall near the forming arch.  Easier to approach from Echoes.

content.description:
This flawless splitter starts as a tight finger crack, and ends as a #3 big bro after 110' of gradually widening.

If it wasn't in the middle of nowhere, it'd probably be a mega-classic. Despite its remote location, it is well worth the hike, and will not disappoint.
content.protection:
In NEW camalots...

1 #.3

2 #.4

1 #.5

1 #.75

1 #1

1 #4

1 or 2 #5

2 #6

Big bros..

2 green ones. #3 i think?
content.location: This route is about a 15 minute hike from the far right end of the Wall. The best approach option would be to park as for the 75 Carins wall (or Election wall as its called in the new guide) and hike directly up the talus in between the Wall, and 75 Carins, aiming for the obvious splitter.
